texts.definition: Objects or information designed to mislead or distract players.
markups: <style="Definition">Objects or information designed to mislead or distract players.</style>

Many games require that players try to figure out the correct or best action, or solve puzzles where not all information is known. <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style>, purposely misleading information or objects, can be inserted into the game to make them challenging. Some games, especially strategy games, also give players themselves the possibility to create <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> for other players in order to distract or deceive them.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Adventure%20Games">Adventure Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Police%20Quest%20series">Police Quest</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zork%20series">Zork series</link></style> often use <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> to give players objects or information that serve no constructive purpose in the games. Sometimes this is only true for a certain time and they can be put to meaningful use but they still serve as <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> up to that point. Similar uses of objects and information can be found in detective scenarios in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conspiracy%20for%20Good">Conspiracy for Good</link></style>) and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> (several examples of this can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallen%20Reich">Fallen Reich</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style>).

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Strategy%20Games">Strategy Games</link></style>, especially <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Real-Time%20Strategy%20Games">Real-Time Strategy Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft series</link></style>, can use some units as decoys in order to lure other players' into placing their units in positions where they are vulnerable to surprise attacks.

Inserting <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> into a game design is basically a case of misdirecting players regarding how they can solve goals, typically <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> related to <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>. This means that <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> also require some level of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> to work. The exception is that players can use <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> to lie about their strategies and intentions even in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perfect%20Information">Perfect Information</link></style> games.

The actual misdirection required of <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> can be constructed by subverting <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>; <style="Link"><link="feelies">Feelies</link></style> can in this context be a special opportunity that combines physical <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> are often <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> but naturally need to appear to be something else to work as such. The use of <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> is one way to provide misleading <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirect%20Information">Indirect Information</link></style> to players through <style="Link"><link="information-passing">Information Passing</link></style>. The other way is to let the other players provide these <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style>. These can be in the form of decoys to help succeed with <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> goals, which may be part of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style> may in effect be <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> since they may intentionally or not distract players from the main goals of a game.

<style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> are typically of a diegetic nature (although some may be more related to game interfaces), so they can be considered <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Diegetic%20Patterns">Diegetic Patterns</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> are often present in <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, especially those using <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style>, to raise the uncertainty regarding how the narrative will progress. It can of course also create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> related to the overall plot besides just momentary ones.

<style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> populate <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> with irrelevant or misleading content. While this can make <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Navigation</link></style> more difficult, it can also support <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> by providing a more believable amount of content. Discovering that <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> are in fact <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> is likely to be a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprise</link></style>, but may also lead to player frustration and work against them feeling a <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>.

The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> means that players have a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> while playing, even if there might only be one "correct" alternative. By thus giving players more potential outcomes from actions and more things to consider while playing the game, <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> can create both <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, and deciding which actions, information, etc. is worth investigating can be a form of <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> in itself. Knowledge that <style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> make exist can modulate <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and lead to increased <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> as players are more uncertain about the effects of their efforts.

<style="CurrentLink">Red Herrings</style> are potentially conflicting with <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> in the sense that what to players may seem the latter can turn out to be the former.
